Award.AwardTitle: DECam Survey for Benchmark 15 Myr-old Substellar Objects in the Nearest OB Association
Award.AbstractNarration:
This will support work using the Dark Energy Camera (DECam) and soon-to-be commissioned TripleSpec4 spectrograph on the Blanco 4-m telescope at Cerro Tololo in Chile to obtain images, astrometry and spectra of relatively young substellar objects in the nearest OB star-forming region, Sco-Cen. The observations will be used to constrain atmospheric models of L- and other brown dwarfs, and to determine what fraction of substellar objects have protoplanetary accretion disks within 15 million years of the substellar objects? formation. The project?s main goals are to greatly improve our knowledge of the properties of young brown dwarfs, help constrain their origins, and observationally constrain the prospects for planet formation around brown dwarfs via their disk lifetimes.

Broader impacts include bringing research into undergraduate STEM-related classes, press-releases, and training undergraduate students in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This program carried out the first deep imaging survey of the two
nearest OB subgroups (regions of recent massive star formation) to the
Sun in order to discover the very lowest mass stars and brown dwarfs
("failed stars"). Our mission was to uncover a large, statistically
useful and representative sample of young objects ranging in mass from
stars a few tenths the mass of the Sun down to the deuterium-burning
limit of about 13 Jupiter masses, down to the regime of planets.
Identification and characterization of a large sample of such objects
can help answer the questions: how can young low-mass stars and
substellar objects be identified using their spectra alone? how long
do planet-forming disks of gas and dust survive around young low-mass
stars and brown dwarfs?  do brown dwarfs form fundamentally
differently from low-mass stars? is the distribution of masses of
low-mass stars and brown dwarfs similar from one star-forming region
to another? The two regions surveyed - called Lower Centaurus-Crux
(LCC) and Upper Centaurus-Lupus (UCL) - are large regions of the
southern sky that include many of the brightest stars in the
constellations Crux ("the Southern Cross"), Centaurus, and Lupus.
There is a large populations of thousands of stars with ages between
approximately 5 and 25 million years old in these regions (mean age
approximately 16 million years), lying approximately 300 to 500 light
years from Earth. The most massive members of those groups are hot,
white-blue, short-lived, massive luminous stars making up some of the
brightest stars in those constellations (e.g. Acrux, Mimosa, Hadar,
etc.). Recent surveys using X-rays and proper motions have yielded
hundreds of lower mass stars similar in mass to the Sun. However to
find the lowest mass stars in the group, and those so low in mass that
they will never stably burn hydrogen ("brown dwarfs", or "substellar
objects" or "failed stars"), we need to use the new multi-CCD Dark
Energy Camera (DECam) on the Blanco 4-meter telescope at Cerro Tololo
Inter-American Observatory (CTIO) in Chile to survey nearly 90 square
degrees. After a challenging effort to reduce and analyze these data,
our survey identified a few hundred new candidate young low-mass stars
and brown dwarfs in the UCL and LCC groups, the first isolated
examples yet found in these groups. Our initial spectroscopic
observations of the first dozen objects have shown that our selection
by colors, brightnesses, and motions was extremely efficient, so we
are confident that most of these few hundred objects are actually bona
fide members of UCL and LCC. We also found that a surprisingly large
fraction of these objects (more than 30%) still appear to have
retained circumtsellar disks by age 15 million years, suggesting that
the material for forming planets is still orbiting these low-mass
objects by this age. These planet-forming disks appear to persist
sysematically longer around the lowest mass stars and brown dwarfs
compared to Sun-like stars or the most massive stars in the group,
indicating a longer, more protracted epoch for planet formation.  Our
spectroscopic survey of these candidates should yield the largest
spectral library of low-mass objects with ages between 10 and 20
million years old, and characterization of these specta will help in
the identification of isolated examples of young low-mass stars and
brown dwarfs. This project has helped in the training of two graduate
students and three undergraduate students (via the REU summer research
program), their education on STEM topics such as observing with
telescopes, data analysis, calibration, and statistics, and training
to be the next generation of scientists. The results from this work
were disseminated in PhD theses, refereed papers, research
presentations and posters, and talks for the public. Ancillary
research results from this research program include the serendipitous
discovery of the closest known past flyby of a star to the solar
system, characterization of a transiting candidate proto-exosatellite
disk orbiting a star in UCL, refinement of the age scale for nearby
young stellar populations, and discovery and characterization of
planetary-mass companions and isolated members of nearby young stellar
groups.
